caption:
This is Energy Ladders, a piece that I recorded by triple-tracking myself playing an FM synthesis patch (the "twist" being that it has an extra cosine applied to the modulated signal) written in Pure Data.

I need a push to reactivate the music writing after having to spend all of my time on other things, so I'm doing this as part of #synthruary, one of those things where you wear yourself out trying to do a thing every day of the month.

    This is Energy Ladders, a piece that I recorded by triple-tracking myself playing an FM synthesis patch (the "twist" being that it has an extra cosine applied to the modulated signal) written in Pure Data.

    I need a push to reactivate the music writing after having to spend all of my time on other things, so I'm doing this as part of #synthruary, one of those things where you wear yourself out trying to do a thing every day of the month.

caption: My second Synthruary song is Message from Afar. It's another low song. I made a simple instrument that shifted the pitch by amount depending on the note in the sequence. It also delayed by an amount based on its position in the sequence. So, it was quite chaotic, though I didn't feel it was completely unrelated to what I was playing on the guitar. I did want a more complex sound than some offset sinusoids, but I had enough trouble as it was.

I did want a more complex sound than some offset sinusoids, but I had enough trouble as it was.

caption:
- Client B work. Five hours of code review. That was actually too much. But now I think I might be in shape to hit my goal, even with missing Monday.
- Client A communication. We are finally talking about payment, which seems unreal.
- Made dinner.
- Messaged some more distant friends I haven't talked to in a while.
- Wrote a pd patch, abstracted an index-ticking thing I can reuse in other patches, put together Message from Afar.

caption: This is Winding Down. I didn't use the Synthruary prompt because I was short on time. Basically, I wrote a tool to graph this into midi. Fun fact: It does not actually slow down.
altText: This is Winding Down. I didn't use the Synthruary prompt because I was short on time. Basically, I w
htmlFragment:
• 2/4/2022, 1:01:55 AM
    This is Winding Down. I didn't use the Synthruary prompt because I was short on time. Basically, I wrote a tool to graph this into midi. Fun fact: It does not actually slow down.

caption:
- Dropped off, picked up, dropped off.
- Client B work.
- Chatted with someone about living in Colorado and various parts of Massachusetts, slime molds, and shaders.
- Read about shaders.
- Wrote a tool to slow down a midi file. I needed it because I wanted to slow one of my songs down, but it's already at the slowest tempo NanoStudio allows. So instead, I have to make every note in the song take twice as long and start later. The tool works, and I exported all of my parts from NanoStudio and slowed them down, but I haven't imported them back to really make sure it all worked.
- Made dinner.
- Client A work. I was going to do this tomorrow, but then I found out about the school closure. I'll have to get the rest in later.
- Wrote a script to generate Winding Down.

I was really hoping to do more leisurely reading-style things a bit today. I also might not get in any vocoder work. Oh, well.

caption:
I got a small mixer partly so that I can play my guitar through an amp modeler on my computer. I like the mixer so far and was able to get a few amp sounds that I like better than what I can get on iOS, but there are issues with it working at the low latency I need it to work at (hence the pops in this recording).

I had to do a lot of poking around just to get sound going. So, I see why so many people prefer traditional hardware devices to software.
altText: I got a small mixer partly so t
htmlFragment:

I like the mixer so far and was able to get a few amp sounds that I like better than what I can get on iOS, but there are issues with it working at the low latency I need it to work at (hence the pops in this recording).

    I had to do a lot of poking around just to get sound going. So, I see why so many people prefer traditional hardware devices to software.

caption:
- Dropped off, picked up.

- Drove the guy to social class. He seems to be doing well there and having fun?
- Got groceries.
- Made dinner.
- Went to the electronic music group. I didn't have much to show but a broken midi generator, and I was wiped (was up until 2 last night wrapping up Client A stuff, though that was because I started late after repeated attempts to make the midi generator work). Still, consistency!
